entry.content:
I solve puzzles.

That may look like observing people work and translating their frustrations into solvable problems. Or maybe designing a solution for someone else to encode in software. Or even writing the code myself. Sometimes it's identifying and removing progress blockers.

Regardless of the task, my work feels like a game when I'm at my best. But it's not just a make-the-numbers-go-up game. I need to know the numbers we track are the right numbers. The right numbers represent both progress and cost to avoid unintentional harm.

I know I've "won a game" when my gut tells me I've distilled a problem to its essence. When the solution is clear and elegant.

entry.content:
My previous home page content feels a little dated, but I feel bad getting rid of it, so I'm keeping it around in the form of a blog post. Here it is.

My name is Curtis Blackwell.

I'm a software engineer and manager. I aim to maintain a sustainable state of:

  • producing high-quality, life-improving work;
  • advancing my knowledge and skills;
  • leaving things better than I found them; and
  • encouraging others to do the same.

I live for work that provides social benefit and revolves around refining operations.

A recent project serves as a perfect example: The Laravel app tracks inventories for a refugee-employing company, helping it operate smoothlier. #2017 #april

It helps the company:

  • import product data from a Shopify store,
  • assign a bill of materials to each product, and
  • create and fulfill production orders.

These features work together to automate changes where possible, like in products' and materials' stocks. The app also sends/receives updates to/from Shopify when appropriate.

In the past, I worked on a coworking space's CMS-powered member/admin dashboard. I planned and built features to:

  • manage members' Stripe subscriptions across multiple Stripe accounts (one per location),
  • send all Stripe transactions to multiple Xero accounts (one per location),
  • allow members to print via Google Cloud Print, charging per-page after using monthly credit, and
  • help staff manage guest tours and send half-canned/half-fresh follow-up emails.

As for JavaScript, HTML, and CSS, there's not much to say beyond, "I'm more than competent." I like Vue and Sass. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

In general, I like to try and keep code as DRY as possible (like Thomas Jerome Newton's home-planet dry), without wasting time on diminishing returns.

I have other skills and traits that prove useful all the time:

  • understanding of design
  • ability to provide constructive, actionable criticism
  • confidence to speak bluntly with the tact to know when to tread softly

…and some less often:

  • mid-level Korean proficiency
  • expert chopstickery
  • ability to open doorknobbed doors with my foot

entry.content:
Just wanted to share a quick little thing I learned you could do with Faker, a library I've been using for years in writing tests.

Fuck context, show me the coolness.

I'm writing tests for an API integration where I need to fake some IDs that, in production, would come from the API. The IDs are always 20–24-character alphanumeric strings.

At first, I thought I might need to do something like use the password method and make sure it was long enough that I could strip out any non-alphanumeric characters. But that felt tedious and over-engineered, so I started thinking about shuffling a long alphanumeric string and truncating it.

Then I noticed the regexify method. It's a little weird to use a searching/matching pattern as a way to generate a random string, but it was simple and intuitive enough.

$this->faker->regexify('[a-z0-9]{20,24}');

entry.content:
A little over 2 months ago, I admitted to myself that I'm burnt out. That I've been burnt out for a long time, maybe even several years.

I recently ended a month-long leave of absence to start my recovery process. I started re-learning how to be a human. Paying more attention to my overwhelmed senses1 and the pains in my body.

I've found that stream-of-consciousness journaling helps me to find peace when I'm feeling overwhelmed. And when I go re-read my thoughts, I often find thoughts I benefit from diving deeper into and organizing. I find little nuggets o' wisdom that help me make more intentional/strategic decisions about what I want to do. I'm starting to recognize more personal agency and feel less like life is happening to me.

So, inspired by people I admire and receive "anonymous mentorship" from, I decided to start publishing some of what I'm learning and thinking about. I hope my writing helps others, similar to how theirs helps me.

P.S.
I love me some Ron Funches and recently discovered his podcast, Gettin' Better with Ron Funches. Just thought it would be a funny name for this. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

  1. I'm an HSP ↩︎

entry.content:
Who/what do my values serve? ➡️ I want to start considering the impact at scale my values have.

Does my vegetarianism matter, for example?

It complicates my life, but doesn't really have much of an impact. There aren't several other people eating vegetarian because I am. It just makes it harder to find restaurants to eat at with friends or work colleagues. The best I can tell, is that it forces others to see how difficult it can be to find viable vegetarian options.

Harder to do things with others. To eat at restaurants. To try things like a keto diet.

Similarly(?) I've never pursued wealth, because I don't really value it. But I do value freedom. I think I want to try and get rich so I can feel secure in doing what I want when I want.

Dictating what I spend my time and energy on.

Feeling like I drive my work rather than my work drives me.

Over 50% of my available time is spent working for a company, but I don't value the work I'm doing.

or resting/commuting/preparing to be able to do the work.

Today I looked at the Teenage Engineering website. I want to buy some Pocket Operators and modular synths to play with. But I know I wouldn't use them since I rarely have the energy when priorities would align.

Or the Mayku Multiplier. This could lead to more fulfilling work and an environment better designed for me. And maybe even creating work for others / helping people escape poverty.

I also have relationships I care about. The time I could spend playing with them is before/after work, but then my energy is low or the environment isn't conducive.
